description:
This restaurant is at the border of San Francisco Chinatown. So, street parking is a possibility. The local merchant recommended this place and warned us of the wait. Yes, the place was packed on a Friday afternoon. Luckily, we scored the last table for two within 5 minutes upon arrival.
After seated, we were asked about what tea we would like to have. Do note that hot tea is automatically charged (per person) whether you drink it or not.
We ordered five items from the menu; three savory and two desserts.
The pan fried lotus roots and pork was the star. It was tasty and the combination of the lotus root & the ground pork matched up so well. Enjoyed every bite of it. The dried scallops and egg white fried rice was OK. The dried scallops were chopped so fine that they were hardly seen or tasted. The steamed beef balls were good. Unfortunately, they might have forgotten this dish as we didn't get them until they served the sweet desserts.
For the desserts, we had the durian rice dumplings and the steamed black sesame balls. The durian rice dumplings actually came with real durian meat inside. Unfortunately, the gooey dumpling did not compliment the durian well. The steamed black sesame balls were good. They just came too early (way before our steamed beef balls showed up). 
Overall, it was OK. If we have to wait in line for this place though, we might choose another place.
author: Andrew L.

description:
This is probably the worst place to eat for dinner  in Chinatown, the food was way too overpriced and they ran out of a lot of food so the options were limited. 

The 3 of us had 4 entrees and 1 rice and it cost $70, the most expensive and below average dinner I've had. 

I would never come back here to eat.
author: Anna L.

description: If you like bug in your veggies with their legs. See photo. Manager removed the dish from the check but we were obviously grossed out.
author: lia m.

description:
We were strolling past the location of our favorite old rice porridge haunt, Hing Lung. While we were looking at the menu posted in the window, the owner stepped out and tried to get us to come in. I was reluctant because they didn't have my fave roast duck jook on the menu. He said they could do that for us, so we thought we'd give it a try.

We're glad we did. We ordered a bowl of plain jook and a small plate each of roast duck and BBQ pork. The jook was as good as that at old Hing Lung: a hint of salt, a few shreds of ginger, substantial and comforting. 

We ordered sesame balls for dessert. Honestly, they were the best we'd ever eaten: crispy, generously filled, and not a bit greasy. The owner stopped by a couple times to check on us, and he seemed to like that we once lived in China and spoke some Chinese. We liked him and his food enough to take a pic with him.

I'm so happy we gave this place a try; it'll be my go-to jook joint next time I'm in town.
author: Patti I.

description: Pro tip: jump in here with a friend and order the half peking duck to split - comes out to about $10 each for an absolutely decadent late night treat. Seriously, I've been to a few peking duck places in Beijing, and the duck here is even better. Super juicy and flavorful.
author: Josh L.

description:
We used to come here frequently for their HK-style food which includes their well known fried donut sticks. Sadly to report, their HK-style food have gone down hill since their revamp for 2018. 

When we sat down and saw the new menus, I was told we can order off menu however, the staff says the prices has increased for the same dishes on their previous menu. I did appreciate the staff for warning me the price difference instead of being surprised with the final bill. We opted to get one of our go-to dish (roast duck noodle soup) to taste if there's a difference. The noodles taste the same but the style of duck they offer is much different. Also, disappointingly, their well known fried donut sticks are far from their previous quality. One of the staff revealed they changed most of their kitchen staff to cater to their new dim sum style menu. We did try two of their dim sum dishes and to my surprise the quality is pretty good. 

What did get me with their new cost structure is that because I'm currently pregnant I've been avoiding caffeine. I asked for hot water in lieu of tea but I was charged the same $1.25 per person tea fee. I asked the cashier about the charge and she said regardless of tea or water there is a "water fee".
author: Mindy C.

description:
My friend and I came on a Friday night. It wasn't busy, but there was probably only 2 workers on the floor. We were seated right away and our tea was brought over to us, but they took a very long time coming around to take our orders. We even motioned for them to come over. It took a few asks before orders were taken. Then the food took Quite awhile to come out. Granted mine was a baked dish, but the fried rice my friend order shouldn't have taken THAT long. 

On a brighter note, they got my friend's order correct because she needed to make a few changes. Also, the baked dish I ordered was decent.
author: Karen Y.

description:
This has been the worst service of my life!! The food is mediocre at best. The service took forever and we had to ask multiple times for sauces that still did not arrive to our table. 
We were seated right away however a seat over from us was an old lady and the manager of the restaurant having a yelling match. The manager yelling at this old lady making her pay for a dish she did not want or order. Another waitress was waving her hand in front of her face and completely disrespecting her. Let's just say this is the last time that I come here and I hope they change up management.
author: Christine L.

description:
Great service (compared to all of Chinatown).

Food is very well done, freshly made, and one of the best HK style cafes in Chinatown. 

Rated by long time San Franciscan having eaten at countless Hong Kong style cafes in the Bay Area. (Chinatown has lost its good cafes due to catering to idiot tourists, but this cafe stands as one of the cafes that maintains standards for HK style food).
author: Gregory F.

description:
I have then one more chance to redeem themselves. 
The food was good. But as you know, service is something can barely find in Chinese restaurant.
author: Parinya W.

description: The stuff said it would be just a few minutes for waiting but we waited for 20 mins. Then we seated in a table for another 10 mins asking for water and menu but we didn't get any because they were too busy. We won't go here again.
author: Angela W.

description: Very good and very fresh.  Made hot to order.   Excellent service.  Very pleasant friendly attentive staff.  Nice place for dim sum in Chinatown
author: Darrell W.

description: Came here with my family for dinner since chinalive had a 1.5 hour wait. The place is super nice and clean but still looked like it had authentic chinese food so we went in. We ordered the $108 set menu for a table of 7 and got the peking duck, house soup, mushroom & abalone, honey walnut prawns, the fried pumpkin shrimp, and the black pepper sizzling beef. We were very surprised with how good everything was! Everything was really well seasoned and came pretty quickly. Even my asian grandma was really pleased with everything so you know its really good. Definitely will come back again!
author: Brianna A.

description:
Seated immediately for lunch, I like the interior it is very clean and spacious. We ordered:
-Wonton Noodle Soup (1/5): I have a lot to say about this dish, first off each wonton had a different flavor (some were too salty and some were too bland) AND the wontons lacked any or little shrimp. The ratio of meat & shrimp was 5:1 (as in after the fifth wonton I finally found a piece of shrimp)?!?!? Also, the portion is very big, as in TOO MUCH NOODLE and not enough soup.... very disappointed in this HK style cafe joint.

-Chinese donut wrapped in rice noodle (1/5): Why is the Chinese donut so damn big and not crunchy whatsoever? It was not satisfying to eat at all, one piece and I was scared to have another. Chewing time was about 10-15 chews to break down the flour-filled donut... 

-HK style Milk Tea (5/5): I really enjoyed this, I thought it had a good balance between the condensed milk and the tea. Not too sweet and with good tea flavor :)
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
Café Broadway is located at the former Hing Lung Restaurant.  It is modern and upscale looking compared to the typical restaurant in Chinatown. Our party of three decided to check it out for lunch on a Friday. A host directed us to one of the booths that are along the side of the dining room. I think a booth is preferable than sitting in a tables in the middle of the dining room, unless you have a party larger than four.  Our waitress then dropped off some menus after we were seated.  After we checked out the menu, we placed our orders when she returned.  As we waited for our food, we were never brought place settings or tea.  Had to flag her down and ask for it. 

Our food:
Beef stew with daikon over rice lunch special. Beef stew had good flavor, but felt the portion of stew was on the small side.  The soup that came with the special was bland.

Won ton noodles. One of my party wanted wide noodles but they were out, so both received the thin noodles.  Five won tons to the bowl, but they were both disappointed with the quality of the won tons.  The won ton skin was thick and the meat was not seasoned well.

Food was below average and though the ambiance was nice, we will opt for another place to dine in Chinatown.
author: Al L.

description: Not sure how I feel about this place. Seems new and clean. Their menu and chef has changed so don't bother looking at the other pics. The two dishes we had were good. The service was very friendly. Entire place was clean. A little on the pricier side for Chinese food, but food is authentic. I would come again if we were short on time and didn't want to wait in line for an hour.
author: N N.

description:
Went for dinner on weekend. Get seated immediately. Ordered the dinner special which came with three dishes and soup, but no rice. Tried beef brisket stew, sticky chicken wings, steamed egg custard with clams. The beef brisket stew was too salty. The wings were ok. The egg custard was surprisingly tasty and prefectly pudding like texture. 

Overall it is a nice and clean restaurant for decent Chinese food. Price is acceptable. Service is alright. Recommend to give a try. They also serve traditional Chinese breakfask like Chinese donuts, rice rolls and porridge in the morning. Would like to try them next time.
author: Yumi G.

description:
Cafe Broadway is exactly what it portrays to be. Comfort, greasy and traditional Chinese food.

Service staff don't look exactly thrilled to be here. The majority of the staff were playing Pokemon Go on their phones before I had to motion for our order to be taken. I also had mixed feelings about the food. The shrimp & egg rice noodle dish is delicious. The wonton noodle soup did not taste that great. The broth is very salty and the wontons obviously have been in the freezer for a long time. 

Lastly, I understand small businesses have a minimum for credit card transactions. But to impose a $30 minimum for card usage is rediculous. How are two people supposed to eat $30+ worth of food when the majority of the menu items are about $10?

With the abundance of options for Chinese food in the area, I would be hard pressed to visit Cafe Broadway a second time.
author: Philip M.

description: Tried this restaurant today at noon. The lobster noodle was pretty good but the dim sums was average.
author: William N.

description: My family and I decided to stop by this place for lunch today. There was about a 15 minute wait which wasn't too bad. We tried the porridge and seafood noodles. The overall quality and taste of the food was pretty good. There was some confusion about them being out of porridge, but it was quickly resolved and we got it. Also I wouldn't expect the waiters/waitresses to come to you. You gotta wave them down. Overall, I would definitely come back again. If you have ever been to the previous restaurant that was located here, I would say the porridge is just as good!
author: Phillip K.

description: Their sticky rice was amazing. Definitely must try. Although it is pricey but all the food we ordered taste delish. The only sad thing is that they do not have milk tea (hot) for breakfast. I was looking forward to eat it with the Chinese donut.
author: Sharon W.

description: :( Ordered Hoi Nan Chicken to go. Ordered it before, I think I got half of the portion of the dish this time, pretty upset about it.
author: Qiaosi C.

description: Come here if you want mediocre service, expensive but meh food and wait staff to hassle you about your tip afterward. The hostess in black had the audacity to ask for a bigger tip than the one we left for her. Lectured her about how the law requires us to pay the bill and tip is voluntary (even though we gave a tip.) She said, "then dont come back here." Needless to say, Took the tip back and we'll be taking their advice and staying away from this S-hole.
author: Derrick C.

description: The food is great here. San Francisco has good ethnic foods. Beware parking is terrible. I had to park in a garage four blocks away.
author: Alan M.

description: Gotta love coming here when you want some HK food or jook. I only ever come here when I am strangely craving jook and I always enjoy it. It's also better with the chinese donut. Mmm. And for the price, who could complain? Recently, I came here after a trip to Italy and was dying for a bowl of jook, and I ordered a watermelon smoothie (the only thing from Italy I missed) and it was sooo yummy. Yes, Cafe Broadway never fails to hit the spot when I need it. Now, I really hate how they keep raising their minimum to use a credit card. That's the most irritating but if you eat here enough, you get used to it I guess.
author: Jenn T.

description: We went here during the Pokemon event which was pretty cool.  The food prices were not bad. Tried the rice porridge which was tasty and good and the donuts I like a lot.  I would recommend going here.
author: Keven W.

description:
Came in for a quick bite to eat with family.  Jah-leung was fine, the donut a little on the big side.  Lobster noodles were probably our favorite item along with garlic pea sprouts and gai-jook (rice porridge with chicken).

Strangely enough, the potstickers took really long to come out and were HUGE... normally big is a good thing, but the inside was cold and uncooked.  Maybe they were frozen before they were fried?  The waitress was very nice about it, and we sent them back to the kitchen.  We weren't charged for them on our bill.

Overall, a decent and solid option for lunch.  The remodeled interior is spacious too.
author: G C.

description:
Great casual eating point for fried donut and porridge. 

First off, it's a really Chinese eatery with modern looking seating. Some dishes on the menu don't have English translation, but no worries, they speak enough to cater to their variety of different customers who come to eat at this joint. The vibe is very casual, and the waiters are polite but it's typical for you to try catch their attention for any service you want. 

Ordered 皮蛋瘦肉粥 (Preserved Egg Pork Porridge), which came in large bowl good enough to split into two. Fried donuts came in two, and they were very flavorful. It was my first time eating fried dough, and it had a hint of salt and sweetness to it. 

Overall, good portions with a total of $13.00 straight.
author: Linda X.

description:
The restaurant that used to be here had great happy hour deals. I can't remember the name and heaven only knows if I reviewed it years ago. The new management totally cleaned this place up. Everything looks brand spanking new. There's a lot to like about Cafe Broadway if you play to its strengths. Otherwise, this may just be another Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.

Their porridge is pretty good here, it's like dense, filling, and there's a buttery-rich flavor about it- maybe they put animal fat in it, I don't know, I'm not an expert on making porridge. I think every table gets an order of Chinese donuts regardless of what you order. I could be wrong, but they bring it out well before the food. I usually order the porridge with intestines and organs and it's pretty good and reminds me of a nice home cooked meal.

Their beef brisket with wonton noodle soup is so filling. The flavor is very tame and safe, be prepared to put some kind of sauce or seasoning in it. The noodle texture was good, but the heartiness of the brisket is lacking. The wontons were fine, serviceable.

What I would recommend against is ordering their lunch specials. $8 will get you Kung Pao Chicken (or an array of other generic dishes), a serving of rice, and some questionably murky soup that is served lukewarm. I would not order off their lunch special menu again.

If you like porridge or maybe wonton noodle soup, check out Broadway Cafe. Do not eat anything else here.
author: Corey P.

description: There was a line during a weekday lunch.  The food is pretty decent where the rice wrapper is very tender, not as translucent as other places.  It is dim sum so expect the wait, about a Jackson ($20) per person, and okay service (never seem to be overly staff at any dim sum place).
author: Tony C.

description: It's been a while since I was last here. The experience this time was less than satisfactory. They also pressured my grandmother into pay more tips then necessary for mediocre service. If your service is good I'd pay. If not, then I'd pay less. If you want to feel them hovering over you until tip is paid, be my guest. Otherwise, avoid this place completely.
author: E C.

description: Worst place I've ever been to in Chinatown. This restaurant makes the other Asian cafes in Chinatown seem like 5 stars. The employees are really quick to sit you down, but after that it's downhill. It took 20 minutes for us to order. Told myself I wasn't gonna be mad if the food was good. I ordered the black bean sauce spareribs over rice; and it was the worst plate I've ever had in my life. There were more onions and bell peppers than there were meat. The spareribs were not tender, nor did they have any flavor. My boyfriend had the Mongolian Beef over rice and I think it was also the worst Mongolian Beef I've ever had. Without wasting anymore unnecessary time, I decided to walk up to the counter to pay. I felt bad that I had to leave a tip, they didn't deserve it.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I would say that Cafe Broadway is about 2.5 stars, but doesn't give me enough reasons to warrant the 3rd star. I came here with high hopes as a lover of Hong Kong-style Chinese food. The decor and customer service were great, but what dragged my rating of Cafe Broadway down was the food.

~ Atmosphere:

It's a tiny, bustling cafe with a modern sleek look. The place is quite busy, so prepare for a loud Cantonese atmosphere. However, they somehow manage to keep this place clean and well managed despite the constant flow of customers.

~ Customer Service:

Efficient, albeit a little bit rushed. I understand they're busy, but prepare to be greeted in frantic manners by the staff as they try to multi-task through all their customers. However, the food did come quickly, which I was happy about.

~ Food:

Where Cafe Broadway fell flat for me. I was really hoping for an awesome experience here given how busy this place was (it MUST be good, I thought).

What we ordered....

- Baked Portuguese Chicken w/ Rice: One of my favourite Hong Kong style dishes. They really skimped on the sauce so it was a really bland dish, but they then tried to make it up by putting a layer of baked cheese over everything. I kid you not, there was more of a cheese flavour than a rich sauce flavour.

- Ho Fun: Again, one of my favourite dishes that ultimately fell flat. The ho fun has the same exact problem as the Portuguese chicken; there was very little flavour. Usually ho fun is supposed to be rich and packed full of flavour, but here I just got a light taste of sweet soy sauce.

---

To be fair, everything was edible. The meats were cooked well and the textures were great. I didn't hate any particular dish but they really skimped on the flavour, turning some of my favourite dishes into bland "meh"s. Disappointing.
author: Clarissa Y.

description: DONT GO!! I would give zero star if I could. Came here for lunch and ordered a roast pork and chicken rice which cost 14.95?!!! I'm from NYC and a dish like that only cost the maximum $6. The quality of the food was so bad and it ruined our appetite for the day. We were so REGRET that we went! STAY AWAY
author: Linda X.

description:
The spot has been vacant for at least a couple of years. In comes, a very clean and dazzling new restaurant that serve Hong Kong-style cuisines.  

But unlike the previous business, the new café is closed much earlier at midnight seven nights a week. 

On my debut of the new restaurant and for dinner, I ordered the Chicken chops in a sizzling plate (whatever that means). For $11.50, I get two boneless chicken breast cooked and battered Hong Kong-style with two huge broccoli florets and a fat scoop of white rice. What I liked about this dish is that the cast-iron platter was still sizzling hot upon arriving to my table. And the chicken pieces were just as good as any other Hong Kong Cafes. My meal also comes with a soothing cup of Hong Kong-style warm cup of tea. My first visit was a success.

On my second visit and earlier in the month of May, I was also her for dinner. And the restaurant was still serving the lunch menu. I took advantage of the lunch specials and ordered the Mongolian-style beef over rice. For $8.95, pieces of beef flanks, onions, peppers in a spicy sauce with a scoop of white rice. Compare to other cafes, the portion is much smaller, but just good enough to feed me. My high-volume eating has decreased in recent years. 

Despite the low-rating from many of the people who dined and wrote a negative review for this new restaurant, I thought the restaurant was pretty good. I am looking forward to be a regular here.
author: Matt G.

description:
Major msg... Clean even though Yelp Warner me about safety and cleanliness issues.

Food is nothing to write home about.
author: David H.

description:
This place use to be one of my favorite restaurants in Chinatown before the reconstruction+ new management now. Getting seated is a headache--make sure you listen closely for your number because there will be old Chinese grandmas who will jump to take your table even when it's not their number being called. Service is also a headache-- even if you manage to get their attention they will forget your simple request for water the second they walk away. The menu is confusing: they're known for congee--- it's not listed on the menu; they offer baked rice-- just kidding they don't, only fried rice and noodles. 

I got the congee with Chinese 'doughnut' and chow fun. The food was alright, a little bland, but I rather have it bland then drenched in MSG or soy sauce. It definitely wasn't like how it was before, but this is a new restaurant with a new owner after all.  I would come back here again but not anytime soon. They're going to need some time to get their stuff together.
author: Jenny N.

description:
Cafe Broadway offers nice seating with a clean and modern atmosphere for those looking to eat some Cantonese goodies.

They put in time to completely remodel the location to be much cleaner and nicer than their Chinatown neighbors. The plating and booths are nice. The music is what you'd expect from a Ranch 99. The service is nice as well.

The food is very average however. I was able to try two porridges and two of their rice noodle rolls. The clam porridge was pretty good as the clams tasted very fresh. The roast duck and bbq pork rice noodle roll was ok at best. The skins for the rice noodle rolls were somehow off in both taste and texture. The flavor was a bit lacking in those dishes.
author: Joshua M.

description:
Cafe Broadway is a good place to eat in China town.The place is clean,the food is good like the porridge and the other Chinese food,the place is big and you are greeted nicely when you arrive and leave.I recommend you to go there to have a dinner with friends.Lastly,the drinks are the best because it has a lot of flavors.


#Should come here to try the best Chinese food!!!
author: Justin H.

description: I guess it's not fair to compare portion sizes and prices available in another city but I'm used to eating Chinese food in Toronto. It does not compare. What we thought we would be getting and what we actually got was quite different. Less BBQ pork was given than expected for the price listed on the menu and it was too sweet for our liking.
author: Wynne L.

description:
Not bad, decided to give this place a try since ABC cafe has been steadily going downhill...

It's really not a bad alternative but not super good either. The wontons only have 1 shrimp in each one so the pork and shrimp ratio is kinda off but it's pretty tasty and not too salty so I dig it. 

They have this beef tongue fried donut thing there that was actually really, really good. I'd definitely go back for that. We went a little later in the day so they were already a little cold but still impressive. Can't wait to try them when they come out freshly made!

Garlic and pepper chicken isn't really anything to write home about it was ok. 

The milk tea was kinda disappointing since there was too much milk esp condensed milk so the whole thing was just too sweet but eh. 

Overall it's not bad, I'd recommend it as a pretty ok alternative to ABC cafe if you're craving HK style cafe food.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
Cafe Broadway took over the Hing Lung spot,  has rotating menus, happy hour before !! a.m. and 3-5:30. porridge is only served during happy hour. flatscreen not operating when present.

eats:
 beef chow fun(8.99)
-beef marinated with baking soda (not healthy), still chewy 
-chow fun silky smooth
--mystery sauce

liver? crepe(4.99)
-chewy, meat adulerated

chinese donut crepe (3.99)
--donut chewy, not so fresh
food just average, not priicey, no tea refill, no checkins

take outs:
-meats adulterated, still not tasty, just chewy, baking soda not healthy...
-booths too cramped.
-was asked for a tip when paying at the counter (by owner?)
told them we had no service
-was told not to come back, they didn't want our business.

.
author: Victor G.

description:
Grease and Salt were the only major attributes that stood out at this resturant. 

The Food:
     
      Prior to arriving at Cafe Broadway (formally known as Hing Lung). I was excited to indulge in their porridge and Chinese Donuts. Much to my dismay the porridge was overly salted, and the donuts were extremely greasy. You may think that it's unfair to the donuts were greasy considering they are fried. However, grease soaking through a paper bag is never a good sign. We also ordered the tomato beef, honk kong style noodles ( lunch menu), and the salted fish and diced chicken fried rice. All three dishes were nothing to write home about. 

The Service: 

      The service at Cafe Broadway was no where near exemplary. It was simply average. 
          
       After being seated we were quick to notice that two plates were missing. We tried flagging down a waiter multiple times, but decided to get the plates are selves from a nearby table. We came during lunch hour and it wasn't very busy. However the waitress failed to fill our water cups. The servers were able to communicate with us in Chinese and English which is a plus.

The Atmosphere:

      Cleaner than most restaurants in Chinatown.

       This place is newly remodeled so the decor seems fairly new. The chairs were comfortable and the bathrooms were very clean. I really enjoyed the open kitchen where you saw the food being prepared. If you aren't paying attention this place could easily be missed. 

All and All:

       Unless you like salt and grease or just have a knack for Hong Kong style food, I don't recommend this place. If you wanted a clean bathroom to use just come here.

Why Three Stars?:

Average food, Average Service, Above Average cleanliness.

I gave Cafe Broadway 3 stars mostly because of the cleanliness. In San Francisco's Chinatown where the places to get asian style food are endless. This place manages to keep a high standard of cleanliness. In and of itself that is worthy of 2 stars. As for the food it's not the worst or the best so 3 stars is average.
author: Camryn L.

description: Changed the restaurant to be a dim sum place rather than a rice and noodles place. Help is a lot more attentive than before, some smiles and lots of thank you when you are leaving. Two little girls working at the register, greeting  customers, seating customers and getting your bill. Dim sum was very good, nice to have a place in Chinatown. Will be back.
author: Poi L.

description: Really bad service.. takes ages to catch the attention of staff, and after you finally get your order, no one cares about you until you ask for a check.. then you got all their attention as they keep asking for more tips! Seriously??? Absolutely Not recommended for visiting. Don't waste your time here, it's not worth it..
author: Svetlana A.

description: The waits here during normal mealtime hours can be horrendous, probably because it's one of the newer and "fancier" HK-style cafes in the area. Luckily we got here fairly early, at least before the waiting area filled up completely (seating and standing room both). Service is of course pretty bad, but that's partly because of how full the place is--you have to flag down a person for everything. But the food is actually quite good, in my opinion better than the one next door. The Chinese fried donut is tasty and not too greasy when wrapped in the rice roll, while their house special rice rolls has flavorful duck and pork pieces inside. I also enjoyed the beef brisket wonton noodle, which was super filling but not too heavy. Hopefully they keep it up and improve their organization--food is on point already.
author: Tony D.

description: Good decent Cantonese food. Service is good which is rare to find in Chinatown Chinese restaurant. Porridge is a little on the watery side but still very good. Poached Chicken is also tasty and goes well with their ginger sauce on the side.
author: Richard H.

description:
Don't come here! Disgusting food! Disappointing .

I came here for dinner and ordered yin yeung fried rice and vegetable asking for less salt on the vegie. First, the fried rice was disgusting , it was a paste of sauce over very little rice. I told the waitress and she INSISTED that is how they make it although I told her that I've had it many times in Hong Kong and throughout the Bay Area and it is not how it is cooked.  She told me to pay for white rice if I wanted to. I explained to her it is not because the fried rice was not enough to eat, it is all sauce and paste, absolutely disgusting. Why would I pay over $13 for fried rice and then having to pay for a bowl of white rice to dilute their grossed out all sauce fried rice ??  Also, they ignored my request and the vegetable was overly salty. 

Service was horrible.  The waitress kept on arguing and insisting that they were right. Ruined my dinner.  Not coming back here again.  The service was equally as bad as the food.
author: AA A.

description: On a sunday family day  i was really craving dim sum , both my parents and i went different restaurants in chinatown and many of them have stopped serving dim sum after 1 , so we came to cafe broadway we ordered chicken feet pork shrimp siu mai tofu bean curd wrap including beef stew noodle soup , fried rice and sizzling foiled pork liver i love that the food came out steaming piping hot it was very delicious , i will definitely come back .
author: Kimmie Z.

description:
The place is great for breakfast because you get a large bowl of porridge with a free Chinese fried donut for about $6.

Lunch is another story, however. I came and enjoyed the cold pork belly, but I was saddened by the Chicken Tofu Pot. These were the most rubbery chicken I have ever tasted, so much that I avoided all the chicken and picked out the tofu. I brought it up with the waitress, but she said it was normal for that dish... hard to believe that and I left very paranoid at how the chicken was obtained.
author: Shelley C.

description:
One of the few restaurants on Broadway that are open later than most others. 

My mother wanted to eat nice warm cantonese porridge "zhou" so we went in when she spotted it on the menu on the window. However, the "zhou" was sold out already so we ordered two different types of rice noodles plates, a wonton soup, fried rice and thick rice paper wrapped around shrimp which were all very filling for 4 people!

But we still wanted the nice warm cantonese porridge so we went back for breakfast the next day! A bowl of zhou is more than enough for an adult so my family and I ordered 4 total. The plain looking one has seafood and a slight flavor. The "little fish and peanuts" zhou is the most savory (my favorite). My mom ordered the one with chunky pieces of pork (or was it lamb...I forgot since I didn't try that one) The zhou is of pleasant consistency not too watery but not too thick either so it goes down easily but fills you up pretty fast. The one with little fish and peanuts also came with 3 "chinese donut sticks" and a "twin" bread. The twin bread is shaped like a football and I usually tear it in half before dipping it in the zhou to eat.

 All in all my family and I were very content with the food for both dinner and breakfast and would definitely go there again!
author: Vivien C.

description: This place is extremely clean. It is definitely not dirty and they redesigned this place entirely. The porridge here is fantastic and the service is also great. It is a family own restaurant so it feels safe!
author: Jasmine G.

description:
This place replaced Hing Lung which was a very popular congee establishment back in the day, abet it was a bit older and the service was eh. I was pretty sad when Hing Lung closed because it was really the only establishment that serves good congee. When my mom told me this place opened I knew we had to come. Her coworkers and her has already been and think its better than Hing Lung. 

First off, it is pretty much the same layout as the old restaurant but with a new slab of paint and decor. To guarantee a seat get here around 11:30am - 12:15pm. They do have plenty of seating. Besides offering your typical HK fair they also have drinks- milk tea, red bean, boba, etc. I ordered a milk tea boba. It was alright. 

We ordered two bowls of the same congee with an order of the two donuts, seafood thin rice noodles, and a smooth egg with beef flat rice noodles. The congee is a thicker consistency of Hing Lung and was pretty tasty. It was great with the long donut. Frankly, I think their donuts are alright. 

They did mess up our order- gave us one bowl of congee and they confirmed our order with the server and gave us the wrong noodles. 

Overall, it is a great place for the congee but everything else you can get at other restaurants in Chinatown. 

Two unisex restrooms in the back. Currently, they are decently clean.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I hope this time around they're going to keep it clean. Quality of foods pretty much the same. Service? Meh. Know what you want, order, eat, split. Credit card charge has a $30 min.
Both types of Chinese doughnut are good. The long, femur-bone-looking one is salty and crunchy. The flat football shape ones (2/order) is sweet. The later is a better choice, especially if you save the leftover for coffee dunking.
author: Hairy L.

description: Only place in chinatown that does the "cow tongue" style fried pastry. Place is clean by chinatown standards and the menu is decent
author: Kenneth L.

description:
We decided to come here since it had just opened and my boyfriend had just come the night before. 

While we were looking at the menu, we watched as another table was served crab and fish ... but wait, there's no visible fish tank in here so where is that coming from? My boyfriend wanted to get order the crab, but when we asked our waiter, he said they brought it somewhere else - same with the fish. 

We ended up ordering some type of fried rice that the waiter recommended, a half of a duck, and pan fried noodles. Nothing special about any of the food, but it wasn't bad either.
author: Michelle C.

description:
It's not Hing Lung.

If that's what you're looking for, that's the important characteristic.

Price is higher (8 bucks for porridge, 6 for shrimp rice rolls).

Porridge is nice but not excellent. Not enough flavor (i had the beef porridge, it's thinner than expected, beef was barely seasoned, not enough green onions or ginger).

It came with the sweet, almost football shaped fried donut ( not the longer fried bread), so that's nice.

Service was decent, although she didn't take credit cards ( gave some lame excuse about it being early, at 10am?) even though the bill was 38 bucks before tip.

Restrooms were relatively clean for Chinatown.

Might come back, they may get better...
author: Mitchell T.

description: Nicely remodeled place. Haven't been here in a while. Pork knuckle was great combination of crispy skin fat and meat. Lobster over noodles was decently priced.
author: Mark C.

description:
Bleck. "Ehh" quality cantonese/vietnamese (wtf) food in the financial district. Walk a couple more blocks and you'll be in Chinatown. 

Thit nuong game soooooooo poor.
author: Jo L.

description: waitress having hard time understanding. ordered it  a bake steak rice and a waitress assume we are in  hurry and keep telling us it will take a long time so They didn't bake it even when we keep telling them we need them baked. Bill total was $37 and we paid with $100 bill. Only changed with 2 single $bills, and keep saying not 10% tip. So how do u want we to tip u with $5 when they can even take my order right with me speak her mother league?
author: David L.

description:
Well, the food looks great, and I did not have any trouble getting card service at all, but the Mongolian dish seemed to have unnaturally soft and slippery meat, and was much blander than it had appeared.

I stopped by only because of the fact that this was the place that the great Ho Sun lorded over a long time ago when the Jade Garden occupied here. Unfortunately, this seems to be just another Chinese eatery. One thing is that it seemed a lot more sanitary than what Yelp warns people. For Chinatown or environs, anyhow.
author: George T.

description:
I've been here a couple of times since the restaurant opened. The first time (which was quite a while back) didn't make much of an impression, but I came again a couple of days ago per friend's suggestion and liked it better. I ordered the sizzling platter steak with black onion sauce and includes a milk tea or coffee. I admit I'm far from being a steak expert but it was among the favorites I remember having for a HK-cafe style restaurant. (Of course I'm not comparing it to fancier places like Ruth's Steakhouse which are at a much different price level.) My friend told me the porridge is very good, better than that of the old Hing Lung here (which was actually my favorite for porridge back in the days). I haven't tried it here yet but it's on my to-do list.

The business did a good job of remodeling the place. For one thing, the bathrooms are definitely much nicer than when this was Hing Lung (which I dreaded using and avoided as much as possible back then).
author: H K.

description:
One of cleanest place by Chinatown I have been n food is pretty decent.
Price is reasonable n convenient location.
author: Michael C.

description: I ordered a Hainan Chicken Rice plate for $11.95 and was given all bones: no chicken leg, no white meat. I complained to the waitress; she was polite but could only offer better pieces "next time"! How hard could it be to just come back with a couple decent pieces of chicken?!
author: Agnes Y.

description: I was in Cafe Broadway last week and had an excellent experience!! The service was friendly and very attentive, which is something I really appreciate when I go out to restaurants. The place itself is super clean and done nicely, despite what it was before. I had the Duck with fried rice, and it was SOOO GOOD!! Portions are definitely worth every penny. I will definitely be coming back and trying everything else on the menu. Yummm!!
author: Hollie M.

description: Great Chinese food! Chinatown in SF really is better than Chinatown in NYC. Ordered so many dishes I don't even remember anymore. The service here is incredible! They even brought out breakfast menu items when it was dinner at our request. Manager served us personally (for no reason it seemed) too. Not a single dish that I didn't like. I would recommend going ham and just taking the rest to go. Also the place is pretty clean despite being located in the sketchiest part of the city.
author: Lucy C.

description:
First time here and it was a great experience. Good food and quick service. You may have to wave the waiters down as they are very busy. Don't expect too much service, it's a Chinese cafe! It's part of the experience really. It's also very clean with nice decor. Kind of rare in Chinatown I must say. 

When the waitress took our order, she was very rushed but she was polite. Overall, everyone was rushed, but very polite and always ended with a thank you. If you speak Chinese to them, it's a plus.

The food was great! Ordered a soy sauce chow mein, porridge and fried donut. Food came fast, it was hot and tasty.

Will definitely come back soon!
author: Weylie H.

description:
First thing that comes into mind when seeing this restaurant...
"WOOHOO HING LUNG IS BACK...kind of."

After about 5 years, there is a worthy successor to the Hing Lung restaurant that got shut down/"under construction". Cafe Broadway is here to stay.

Ambiance is definitely nicer than before, and probably better than most restaurants in Chinatown. I am in love with the backsplash, colors, everything. Everything is clean.

Food is on point. The beef chow fun simply tastes of higher quality than other chow funs I had around the Bay Area. We ordered the watercress congee and it still tasted great. Still on top of my, admittedly, very short top congee list, but it's still good trust me! The wonton noodle soup was great as well.

THE COW TONGUE DONUTS ARE BACK.  I have been waiting for 5 years. And they still taste the same. I had to knock down ~.5 stars because it came out cold. (no one really likes cold donuts, do they?)

Please definitely give this place a try. I do not understand such low ratings, because I believe this is a great restaurant that does do Hing Lung justice.
----
If you were a Hing Lung fan, the prices are basically the same except a dollar more. The kitchen in the front is still the same. Bookshelf in front of the restroom? Noted for feng shui.
author: Vanessa P.

description:
Came here for breakfast expecting a typically Hong Kong style cafe. Nope! They pretty much only have congee and it comes with hot tea or coffee - not to be confused with milk tea :-/ 
The congee was good, perfectly cooked and came with a half order of fried dough which is nice. But it's a bit on the pricier side. With tip and tax, the congee came to $10...and it's just not worth it.
author: Bonnie S.

description: I want hing lung back!! Congee and food was way better. They need to hire more staff as well.
author: Nart T.

description:
Second time here in two days - partially because I left my sunglasses here the first time. 

Food is pretty good. Maybe not amazing but pretty darn good for someone who haven't had HK style food in a few months. Dishes seem pretty authentic HK style. 

Service is really good. It's busy 7pm dinner time right now and I'm a solo diner. But they have been super attentive to refilling tea, taking my first order, as well as my later to-go order.  Staff have been courteous and I see guests being greeted promptly on entry as well as exiting.
author: B. L.

description:
If I can give them no star I would do that.
I came here for dinner today and I look through the whole menu and there are couple must try so I'm about to order and the waiter comes and tell us about half of the menu the chef is already off work. She will tell you the chef is off work at 4 and the only thing available is the fried rice and chow mein and chow fun. Don't waste your time going there after 4.
author: Vicki H.

description: Wasn't impressed.noisy.sounds echo off walls. This restaurant doesn't cater to the  older to chinese people,but to the younger.service was terrible.hostess more interested in seating people than service.very disorganized. Liked restaurant before remodeling.food was not tasty.this fad will not last very long in this area of chinatown.got to cater to the natives
author: Gary L.

description:
My family decided to stop by since it's been years since we've last been. The place is totally remodeled! We got our usual dish as an appetizer and it ended up smaller than before. 

I got the beef chow fun as my entree and it is flavorless. The service could be a WHOLE lot better. I asked for a taro milk tea with boba and 20 mins later into eating, the same server I told my order to was like oh.... I didn't know you placed it. Geee thanks -_- We asked for water when the server took our order and we didn't get it until we asked someone else 15 mins later. 

You could get better food somewhere else!
author: Ashley D.

description:
On my toes the whole time here since the yelp reviews showed no mercy

FIRST IMPRESSIONS: 
First off, very nice interior. I was impressed by look of this place. The place holds a nice atmosphere that feels like a nice place to sit and just chill. Great place if you wanna hang out with friends. Very loud because Asians .

SERVICE: 
Missed the mark for this one to be honest. Literally no one of the tea refills, I had to ask a few times to refill my tea. The waiter asked me if the dish was correct and I was kind of surprised because of the disorganization. A waiter is suppose to know what you've ordered, maybe it's just that dude. The same guy was also confused about my bill and had to double check with me if it was right. 

FOOD:
I only got the salt and pepper wings and I can tell you that was bomb. The seasoning was proper and the bite was crispy, tender, and juicy. Although a bit pricey but the spices game was a nice addition to the wings.

DRINKS:
Didn't order anything special, just had regular tea. The tea was great, very bold and nice flavor.

TL;DR:
Below average service, great salt and pepper wings, great tea. Nice atmosphere and a great chill place. Noise level is very berry high. Give this place a shot, not as bad as others say.
author: Tim W.

description:
If anyone remembers what this place used to be, you'll be happy that I got instant nostalgia. 

This place used to be an extremely popular chinese restaurant specializing in congee/porridge. It closed down years and years ago and has reopened under a new name and probably new management but I do have to say, food is very similar. 

You really have to know what to order. I wouldn't waste my time or money on items in the menu like spaghetti or pork chops. Instead get the congee, noodles, and try the chicken. 

The service I thought was good, servers were efficient and did their job, they did have to be reminded about items that were taking a little long; but I couldn't care less because for me, it's all about the food.
author: Ingrid H.

description: I had the roast duck wonton soup! It was amazing!! Maybe my taste in roasted duck and wontons are different from some folks but it was so memorable, getting a second bowl for dinner!
author: Jen H.

description: Not a bad place for porridge, other dishes are small and kinda average. Service is a bit too slow. Seating is comfortable compared to other restaurants in the neighborhood
author: Roy O.

description: I like duck noodle soup ,very delicious same as my hometown ,and the restaurant environment is very good ,waiters are very enthusiastic @@ @@ @@
author: Hebe L.

description: Best preserved egg and pork rice porridge w/ fried dough combo in SF. I always get an early morning takeout whenever I can over the weekends. Even my 2 year old love their porridge.
author: Moses T.

description: The Chinese doughnut here is good but unfortunately the fish porridge and noodle that we ordered weren't. Feel bloated afterwards too for some reasons. No credit cards for bill less than $30.
author: Elena H.

description:
I was hesitant to come here due to the low ratings but realized that most of them are regarding poor service. 

Food: I got a duck leg noodle soup and it really hit the spot on a chill day. You don't 100% have to order exactly what the menu says. I wanted different noodles (altering my order slightly) and got them no problem. My duck portion was awesome! Double of what I usually get in NYC! 

Service: people can't expect top notch service in chinatown. It's just not realistic. I admit they're somewhat disorganized here but the servers seem to be trying. 

Overall: I'd come back. It a nice environment to sit, enjoy a meal and the food is reliable.
author: Renee S.

description: I must say this place is pretty damn disappointing. I came here with my girlfriends for afternoon tea. Serval problems at this restaurant.. My friends helped me order chicken wings with fries, one waitress said they don't have chicken wings with fries, the other said they do... how do you not know what is served at the restaurant?! Chicken wings came and there was like maybe 7 pieces of fries on the plate Wtf stingy asses. The chicken wings was also nasty the batter was thicker than the meat itself and it made the meat look almost raw on thr inside but without the blood. Service is slow here even though during hh there's hardly anyone eating here, food is white people price.. my wings was 9 bucks without tax or tips yet and place is actually pretty dirty.. they got a rating of 75. I actually left the place feeling like I didn't eat late lunch yet.. Lets just say I won't be back.
author: Lily Y.

description: Cafe Broadway was one of the better Chinese restaurant that we've encountered during this trip to SF.  The place was packed when we got there, and there was a short waiting list.  But after putting our name down with 4 parties ahead of us, they managed to seat us within 15 minutes.  Most of the food we ordered was pretty good.  This included their Hoi Nam Chicken, Clam Porridge, Curry Fishballs, House Special Look Funn, and Pork Liver & Kidney.  These all came out authentic, delicious, and fresh tasting.  The one thing that left me disappointed was their Wonton & Beef Brisket Lo Mein.  The noodles were not chewy/"bouncy" enough.  All you Hong Kong style noodle aficionados know what I'm referring to.  The wontons were decent, but the brisket was almost inedible.  The brisket was undercooked, and most parts of it that included tendon was very hard and chewy.  This was probably the worst chinese style beef brisket that I've ever had in my life......no exaggeration here.  Service was definitely subpar due to the fact that they forgot one of our orders and were reluctant to let us cancel it.  It came out after we were done eating ALL the other items that we ordered at the same time!!  All in all, this is a decent place to enjoy some chinese food as long as you don't mind below average service.
author: Steven L.

description: Place looks better after the remodel. The service is horrible. It's hard to eat the food when a high-powered fan is two feet away. Asked three times to turn the fan around; I even got up to move it myself, but the workers kept moving it back. They were quite rude about it. Couldn't enjoy the food since it got cold within minutes. Would not recommend, and definitely not coming back.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Terrible service, Tasteless congee with minimal amount of ingredients, rice noodle roll was alright, calamari was overly greasy. In addition, the utensils smell kinda funny! The wait was pretty short on a Saturday, at lunch hour, though!
author: Audrey H.

description: Been here a couple of times but didn't really check in. Food is pretty good and the prices here are pretty cheap. You can get stuff for less than ten bucks and be full. Today I had a friend join me for dinner and we ordered some chicken dish and rice and some beans and three dishes for like $25 or something and we had take out also. The location is a good location and the food comes out pretty good and pretty fast. And for desert you can get some water melon drink or some mango pudding or my favorite Chinese herbal jelly which is good for you.
author: Kyle C.

description:
because it was so full at lunch I was expecting the food to be good,but it was average at best

I had the beef with scrambled egg,there was very little egg and it was in a soup egg and beef is not served as a soup ,and was expensive about 40% more expensive than other places and did not taste half as good,looking around plate sizes are very small,i get double the amount  at other places,i looked up wikapedia to see the name of this style of cooking (Peasant foods are dishes specific to a particular culture, made from accessible and inexpensive ingredients, and usually prepared and spiced to make them more palatable in this case they use soup  ) it cheap food but not that great tasting,but at this place they charge a premium price ,i am surprised at how full it was,they rush you off the table,after about 10 minutes,i would give this place a miss
high prices crowded poor quality poor food poor value ,
plates were old and used
author: cc c.

description:
My family and I decided to come and try this new place out since the last restaurant closed a couple years ago. First of all, the service was okay... No one came around to refill our tea. We had to ask multiple times and most of the waitresses ignored us when we wanted to order food. I ordered the wonton noodle soup and the noodles were hard. It was DISGUSTING!!!! The drinks were EXPENSIVE!!! I ordered a iced lemon tea and I couldn't believe how small the portion was. It was the size of the teacup they gave us and it cost $3.75. Then when the bill came, I found out it was $4.05? WTF??? For that small portion!!!  I asked the waitresses and they each told me a different price for the drink. Eventually the manager showed up and told us it was including tax. What?? Seriously??? Then I looked at the end of the bill and they charged the rest of the tax for the food. Wow!!! If I would 've known the drink was that small and expensive, I wouldn't have ordered it. the only thing I liked about this place would be the interior design. That's probably it.

TIP: They do NOT accept credit cards. CASH ONLY!!!
DO NOT order the wonton noodle soup or any drinks. Not worth the price. Can get twice the portion at a local boba place
author: Natalie G.

description:
You just earn your first amazing review. New restaurant, new owner, worst service, gave me nothing i ordered. When we get into this restaurant, no one served you. You have to stand and stare at them. There are people fooling around, not doing anything. The really short hair guy took my order, saying i want to order black pepper chicken steak sizzling platter. He say "no sizzling platter, oh, i can TRY to get you one."  My friend order Portuguese Style Baked Chicken Over rice. He say "no baked". FINE. We ordered both and chicken sizzling platter DIDN'T came with sizzling platter and portions are half. TASTE AWFUL! I HAVEN"T TRY ANYTHING THAT TASTE LIKE SHIT. Worst customer service.

They also mess up the bill. wrong price and they try to steal your money by getting something you didn't order on the receipt. PLEASE LOOK AT THE RECEIPT BEFORE PAYING!!!!!!!!


Perhaps I should wear my fancy shirts and pants or suits in this little cafe in CHINATOWN!!!!


NO NEXT TIME. FUCK YOU ALL!!!
author: Sandra C.

description: I went in the restaurant last night, ordered the Taiwanese milk tea and the beef steak. I emphasized I want "Taiwanese" milk tea for 3 times, but the waitress gave me a Thai milk tea instead. And the steak was really small, that steak was restructured beef. Moreover, the price of the steak was almost 14 bucks. The waitress was also trying to get higher price steak as well, glad I didn't do it. I got 17 bucks as total, this is a very disappointing restaurant. Highly "not" recommended!!!
author: Ho Jui C.

description: This place is horrible. The service is absolutely terrible. I had to go get utensils my self. Their steak are dry and chewy. The beverages are small. The plate and forks are dirty. The place used to be good but not anymore
author: Vincent H.

description: Still need room for improvement... it's not known on their menu that its Hong Kong style food that's good, it's other items...
author: M W.

description:
Reason for going: had walked by and saw that they had reopened, formerly known as (Hing Lung). keep in mind, I was very excited to go here
Food: They used to be known for their porridge, so I ordered the thousand year old egg with pork. The porridge came out very bland and watery. Very disappointing. They still serve You Tiao (fried breadstick) and Cow Tongue (Fried sweet donut) ($1.50 and $2.00 each!!!) The sweet donut was the only item that was consistent from the previous restaurant.

Final thoughts: Customer service was horrible. The servers absolutely do not cater to elderly people, or anyone for that matter. To put it simply, they are slow to take your order but fast to give you the check. We had 4 servers at each corner of our long  table, and each server was having a casual conversation while there were people waiting to be seated, have their orders taken, you get the idea. Word of advice, if you open a restaurant in chinatown, take care of the natives first, especially the elderly. Will not be back here again. I paid cash, not sure if they take card. Porridge was $6.95  a fried donut $2.00 so breakfast would be around $8.95 before tax. Will not be back for mediocre food, the service was the biggest turn off, the porridge was very bland and watery, and the portions for regular food (beef chow fun) looked like it had been eaten before they brought it out.
author: David W.

description: Great authentic Chinese food (and that's coming from a Chinese person)! The service was efficient, and the restaurant had beautiful plating!  Additionally, the restaurant was very clean and welcoming.
author: Nancy L.

description: The special fried rice they recommended is excellent. Beef chow fun is good. Milk tea is so so. Service is good. I will come back again.
author: Eliza N.

description: While I reminisce about the previous place, this fancy and hipper Chinese porridge restaurant is still pretty good. In particular, I like their variety and prices on the lunch specials. I tried their tofu with fish rice plate for under $9. While it's obvious that it's just tilapia, the portion sizes are huge and filling. I also shared the Wonton noodles and their eggplant stir fried noodles, average but filling Chinese food in a clean setting.
author: Nancy Y.

description: i went to buy cow tongue bread?? Not sure what it's called... and the employee that was giving me the bread looked at me in the eye and picked out the smallest one out of all of them. I paid money in order to eat this and that's the treatment I get? I rather not go anymore.
author: Becky Y.

description: I give one star because I can't proceed with this review without giving any star.  This is cafe in Chinatown with BBQ menu which mean most of the food already precooked. It took me more than an hour to get BBQ pork Lo Mein, which nothing on this dish has to be cooked. When I sat down already bad feeling when the waiter served the customer who came after me.  After almost 15 min I have to call her to get my order.  And overall it took 2 hrs from I sat down to getting my bill.  Nobody refill our tea.  They are not even full.  Avoid this place unless you have the whole day free. Service horrible, food just so so.  I can't believe this place getting 3 star. Maybe family and friends review :)
author: Gloria N.

description: My friends and I came here for a late lunch a few days back and we ordered a Mongolian beef with rice and hainan chicken rice. The chicken was fine but the beef was cold so we told the waitress. 10 mins later she came back with the exact same plate of beef that they fucking MICROWAVED. Like uhm excuse you?? I told you my food was cold and u couldn't even have the decency to just remake it but u microwaved it??? What kind of fucking restaurant is that? If u can't cook don't be a chef. We got the bill and we have $1 tip Bc of the bad service but the waitress asked us for another $1. Wtf??? Really? You're going to ask for tip when u gave us cold food??!!! Come on dude lol
author: Michelle K.

description: Not good. Tea has oil in it. The restaurant was packed and loud, very slow service. Ordered vermicelli with eggplant, the vermicelli was hard.
author: Karen L.

description: Food tastes great and the restaurant is very modern and clean. Definitely recommending!
author: Janice V.

description: I had the peanut & dried fish porridge & steamed shrimp rolls.  The porridge is sizzling hot and has lots of peanuts which is how I like it .  However, the consistency is a bit watery to my liking and there is not enough dried fish, which is supposed to give the porridge it's signature taste.  So one star deducted.  The steamed shrimp rolls are perfect.  The softness of the wrapping compliments well with the crunchiness of the shrimps.  Plus the sweetened soy sauce, I can't ask for anything more.  I wish I had room for the Chinese fried donuts which should go very well with the porridge...maybe next time!
author: Angela Y.

description: Was brought here by a friend, and was very impressed with the food! Delicious chicken feet and ma po tofu. The interior of the restaurant was very nice too.
author: Andrew W.

description: I had the tofu and fish lunch special and it came with a bowl of tomato soup. The dish was tasty. The restaurant also serves porridge and Chinese doughnuts (the sticks and the horseshoe kind) as before. Lunch specials are around $9 a plate.
author: Ann H.

description: Don't come here expecting Hing Ling porridge. Smaller servings, higher prices, and slower service. The restaurant is a lot cleaner than what it was before though!
author: Binh L.

description: So it was just half an hour ago, feeling a little hungry, then I walked into Cafe Broadway, asking what's the minimum amount of money I need to spend in order to swipe card. So the waitress told me that I have to spend a minimum of ＄30, so I was shocked and asking her "really, minimum ＄30?" how does she expect one person to spend over ＄30 for one person meal, right? Her instant reply was that something like well, you don't have money, then don't eat here. I was pissed and said " not that I don't have money" come on, do you expect someone who's only 90 lbs to order over 3 or 4 dishes and eat by herself? She can literally tell how small and skinny I am! And, How can she say such things like I can't eat there because of my financial status? Plus how can you tell how much money I have on my card? I was dressed properly and clean. I feel strongly offended, feeling the discrimination just for asking for clarification of price  against me Moments later, she's like ok fine, since you're by yourself, you still need to spend at least ＄10 something(it actually means roughly ＄10-15ish around that amount (十几蚊）from this you can tell that she's not trying to be nice and help me out, but trying to squeeze every penny that she can. I can literally go to the store right next store, but I chose here just because the food there is decent, but I would never go back there because of the horrible customer service!
author: Lisa H.
